Award.AwardTitle: CI-EN: ORBIT GEN 3 - Enhancing the ORBIT Testbed with LTE and Cloud Radio Processing

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is aimed at a third-generation equipment upgrade for the ORBIT (Open Access Testbed for Next Generation Wireless Networking) testbed which has been operated by Rutgers University as a community resource since 2005. The ORBIT testbed, which researchers access remotely over the Internet, provides a flexible, scalable and reproducible platform for conducting wireless network experiments. ORBIT lowers the barrier for experimentation in the area of radio and wireless technology and thus improves education and research productivity in the field. The goal of this project is to extend the testbed to incorporate two key new capabilities: (1) LTE (Long Term Evolution) radio access, to support realistic evaluation of future mobile data services, and (2) "cloud radio" processing to enable experimental studies of emerging "5G" radio access technologies. The proposed testbed enhancements will help accelerate the pace of wireless/mobile technology development by facilitating evaluation of emerging radio technologies and network architectures such as dynamic spectrum access, cooperative MIMO (multiple input multiple output) and heterogeneous cellular networks. More specifically, the LTE and radio cloud capabilities to be added in this project will enable the study of techniques for enhancing wireless system capacity, helping to address the important societal problem of spectrum scarcity as mobile data usage continues to grow exponentially.

The ORBIT upgrade proposed here involves two major enhancements to the testbed. First, both the radio grid emulator and the outdoor ORBIT campus network will be upgraded to incorporate LTE in addition to the existing WiMax capability. LTE is rapidly being deployed in 4G cellular systems worldwide, and it is important to enable the research community to use this access technology for realistic mobile network experiments. LTE capability will be added to the outdoor ORBIT network by retrofitting a commercial base station to be controllable through the ORBIT management framework (OMF), while LTE on indoor nodes will be implemented in software running on available SDR platforms. Second, the radio grid's backend will be upgraded with a unique combination of FPGA and CPU based "software radio cloud" that will increase processing speeds by two orders-of-magnitude. The proposed radio cloud is designed as a hierarchically organized high-performance system which includes fast CPU-based servers, FPGA co-processors and "thin-client" software-defined radio nodes all connected together by a fast and programmable switching backplane. The system will include nearly 16 compute server blades (each with rated computing capacity of 700 GIPS), a large FPGA-based centralized co-processor array, a total of about 48 software defined radio (SDR) client nodes and about 128 x 10Gbps OpenFlow switch ports for connectivity. Examples of experiments that will be enabled include LTE-WiFi interworking, LTE-based mobile cloud services, wideband spectrum sensing and dynamic spectrum access algorithms, massive MIMO (multiple input multiple output) and cooperative PHY, cellular cloud RAN (radio access network) and virtual wireless networks. LTE capabilities will be released during year 1 of the project, and a first version of the radio cloud will be released in year 2, followed by an updated version in year 3.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was aimed at a strategic "Gen 3" upgrade of the ORBIT (Open Access Testbed for Next Generation Wireless Networking) testbed to significantly enhance and extend its utility as a community resource for experimental evaluation of future wireless and mobile networks.  Since its release in 2005, ORBIT has become a widely used CISE community resource for evaluation of emerging wireless network architectures and protocols. As of 2019, there were over 1700 registered ORBIT users who have conducted a total of over ~400,000 experiment-hours on the radio grid testbed to date. A wide range of experiments have been conducted on the ORBIT radio grid addressing research topics such as network coding, ad hoc network routing, dynamic spectrum access, WiFi network cooperation, wireless network virtualization, future Internet architecture, vehicular networks, and cloud services. These experimental studies have led to over 150 published papers with more in the pipeline.  The ORBIT testbed is also being used to support a number of campus wireless network deployments in the GENI (Global Environment for Network Innovations) program, and the ORBIT Management Framework (OMF) software is being used as one of the control frameworks in GENI as well as in several other testbed projects worldwide. ORBIT has also been used for a US Army project aimed at evaluating routing protocols for tactical mobile ad hoc networks, and as the platform for the first DARPA Spectrum Challenge held in 2013-14.

The third-generation ORBIT upgrade project ("Gen 3") carried out in this CI project resulted in two key enhancements to the testbed.  First, both the radio grid emulator testbed and the outdoor ORBIT campus network have been upgraded to incorporate LTE (4G Long Term Evolution) cellular radio access in addition to the previously available WiMax capability.  The project team worked on an ?LTE kit? by retrofitting a commercial LTE base station to make it controllable through the ORBIT management framework (OMF), as well by developing an open-source software based "open LTE" implementation that runs on software defined radio (SDR) nodes on the testbed.  A massive MIMO rack consisting of several software LTE radios with configurable antennas was also released for experimental use on the radio grid testbed.  Second, a major upgrade of the radio grid testbed's compute backend infrastructure was implemented with the addition of FPGA (field programmable gate array) and NVIDIA GPU enhanced compute boards necessary to realize emerging "cloud radio access network (CRAN)" architectures and to increase experimental compute processing capability by orders-of-magnitude.  The project also integrated a "CloudLab" rack from a synergistic NSF project to provide additional edge cloud capabilities to experimenters.

Examples of ORBIT experiments that are now supported by the new LTE capability include evaluation of WiFi/LTE coexistence in dense environments, or the study of content delivery techniques to LTE-based mobile devices in both emulated and real-world settings.  The GEN3 radio cloud upgrade supports new experiments such as cooperative spectrum sensing in which data from multiple sensors is processed in real-time to obtain RF maps over a given area.  Another type of experimental scenario that can be studied with the enhanced testbed involves centralized radio resource management across multiple access points and clients in a large enterprise or campus network, typically involving dynamic spectrum access.  The upgraded testbed also supports experimentation on a broad class of real-time cyber-physical applications which require low-latency cloud processing and benefit from the high performance edge cloud capability of the upgraded ORBIT testbed.  In addition to research use, the industry-led ONF Wireless Working Group is currently using ORBIT as the platform for Open Network Automation Platform (ONAP) inter-operability standards testing of emerging software-defined wireless networks.
